### Problem

Since `libluv-1.44` neovim build fails with

```bash
âžœ  build-1.45 git:(v0.9.4) âœ— make
[  0%] Built target update_version_stamp
[ 92%] Built target nvim
[ 92%] Built target nvim_runtime_deps
[ 92%] Generating nvim.pot
dyld[9773]: Library not loaded: libluv.1.dylib
  Referenced from: <3DE9CF70-55FA-330B-8A0B-BD1AC36221DE> /Users/ialberto/workspace/repos/neovim.git/build-1.45/bin/nvim
  Reason: tried: 'libluv.1.dylib' (no such file), '/System/Volumes/Preboot/Cryptexes/OSlibluv.1.dylib' (no such file), 'libluv.1.dylib' (no such file), '/usr/local/lib/libluv.1.dylib' (no such file), '/usr/lib/libluv.1.dylib' (no such file, not in dyld cache), '/Users/ialberto/workspace/repos/neovim.git/build-1.45/src/nvim/po/libluv.1.dylib' (no such file), '/System/Volumes/Preboot/Cryptexes/OS/Users/ialberto/workspace/repos/neovim.git/build-1.45/src/nvim/po/libluv.1.dylib' (no such file), '/Users/ialberto/workspace/repos/neovim.git/build-1.45/src/nvim/po/libluv.1.dylib' (no such file), '/usr/local/lib/libluv.1.dylib' (no such file), '/usr/lib/libluv.1.dylib' (no such file, not in dyld cache)
/bin/sh: line 1:  9773 Abort trap: 6           ../../../bin/nvim -u NONE -i NONE -n --headless --cmd "set cpo+=+" -S /Users/ialberto/workspace/repos/neovim.git/src/nvim/po/tojavascript.vim /Users/ialberto/workspace/repos/neovim.git/build-1.45/src/nvim/po/nvim.pot /Users/ialberto/workspace/repos/neovim.git/runtime/optwin.vim
make[2]: *** [src/nvim/po/nvim.pot] Error 134
make[1]: *** [src/nvim/po/CMakeFiles/translations.dir/all] Error 2
make: *** [all] Error 2
```

Previously, all `neovim` builds were implicitly going for the static version of `libluv`, due to

https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/1094d0c0dbd0f37ccc0f1d18c73c6066e5690664/cmake/FindLuv.cmake#L2

Indeed, up to `libluv@1.43` (included) the library names were

```bash
lib
â”œâ”€â”€ libluv.1.43.0.dylib
â”œâ”€â”€ libluv.1.dylib -> libluv.1.43.0.dylib
â”œâ”€â”€ libluv.dylib -> libluv.1.dylib
â”œâ”€â”€ libluv_a.a
â”œâ”€â”€ lua
â”‚Â Â  â””â”€â”€ 5.1
â”‚Â Â      â””â”€â”€ luv.so
â””â”€â”€ pkgconfig
    â””â”€â”€ libluv.pc

4 directories, 6 files
```

So the first entry `luv_a` was matching with `libluv_a.a`, the static library, and it was getting used.

From `libluv-1.44` on, the library names have been changed (see https://github.com/luvit/luv/commit/9d602ab12654d3adb53f34457390f534eb85f5d6) so the situation now is

```bash
lib
â”œâ”€â”€ libluv.1.44.2.dylib
â”œâ”€â”€ libluv.1.dylib -> libluv.1.44.2.dylib
â”œâ”€â”€ libluv.a
â”œâ”€â”€ libluv.dylib -> libluv.1.dylib
â”œâ”€â”€ lua
â”‚Â Â  â””â”€â”€ 5.1
â”‚Â Â      â””â”€â”€ luv.so
â””â”€â”€ pkgconfig
    â””â”€â”€ libluv.pc

4 directories, 6 files
```

So static libraries does not have anymore any name based priority, and the shared library is picked first.

This does not represent a problem on linux, where it still works correctly, but on macOS the RPATH management seems not working correctly.

It is probably due to the custom basic `FindLuv.cmake` CMake module, which should be probably improved in order to deal also with the more requiring RPATH management on macOS (not an expert, but probably it requires @rpath/libluv.dylib` or something like that as library name). Not sure, but if the detection is improved and cmake targets are used, it would be probably easier to let CMake do the right thing also on macOS.

### Steps to reproduce

Just try building on macOS any neovim version (tested with 0.9.0 and 0.9.4) using as dependency `libluv-1.44` (tested with 1.44.2-0, 1.44.2-1, 1.45.0-0) will fail as soon as build starts using the `nvim` executable because it does not find `libluv` dynamic library.

comment_data.body:
> if the detection is improved and cmake targets are used, it would be probably easier to let CMake do the right thing also on macOS.

Uh, this kinda sounds like "if we improve the files then the files will have been improved". Do you have any concrete proposals or suggestions?

Also yeah, do try the suggestion from the spack person to see if it solves the problem.

I'm back! Thanks to @haampie ("the spack guy"), who immediately spotted the problem, now it works.

The problem is as described above, i.e. on macOS if `neovim` ends up using dynamic library for `libluv` it does not work (since long ago), but the problem is imputable to `libluv` requiring an old CMake minimum version (ending up not using new policies, in particular ([CMP0042](https://cmake.org/cmake/help/latest/policy/CMP0042.html).

I would say that this does not require a fix on `neovim` side, since it should be `libluv` installing correctly the dynamic library with the `@rpath` tag in it. Actually `libluv` in the next version (1.46) is going to require a newer minimum CMake version, which will enable implicitly the CMP0042, solving the problem also on macOS.

I don't know if you'd like to specify this constraint about `libluv` somehow in neovim. Up to you.

Anyway, for what concerns the original reason for opening the issue, I would consider it solved. Hence I will close it and I will link to this issue for future reference (mainly in the spack package).
Thanks for the follow-up. I don't think we need to do something from our side, cmake has deprecated versions 3.4- and our dependencies should be bumping their versions in their upcoming releases.

title: Problem with RPATH on macOS "Library not loaded: libluv.1.dylib".
